Britain said it was sending warships and troops to help citizens who want to flee.

Putin Takes Oath of Office Vladimir V. Putin swore to ''respect and guard the human and civil rights'' of Russia, and officially became its second president. He reappointed as acting prime minister Mikhail Kasyanov, left, known to the West for his dealings on rescheduling Russia's foreign debt.

Rwanda Ready to Exit Congo Rwanda said it was ready to begin withdrawing its troops from Congo, a step that members of the United Nations Security Council say could be the first real opening for negotiations to end a two-year war that now involves six African nations.

Euro's Decline Creates Concern Since its debut as the official monetary measure of Europe, the euro has plunged 24 percent, bringing with it a debate about the reasons for the decline. The turn of events has confounded currency strategists and economists and reignited suspicions among Europeans who never liked giving up their old currencies.
Tehran Elections Under Fire Iran's conservatives charged that parliamentary elections in Tehran had been riddled with fraud, raising the chances that they could annul the reformist victory.

Third Zimbabwe Farmer Killed A white farmer died today after he was beaten unconscious yesterday by suspected liberation war veterans leading the violent seizures of white-owned farms. Alan Dunn was the third white farmer to die since veterans began invading farms in February.

North Korea-Australia Ties North Korea said it had agreed to restore diplomatic relations with Australia after a 25-year freeze that North Korea had initiated. It was the latest sign of a diplomatic offensive by North Korea. The announcement was made on North Korea's official radio, monitored in Tokyo.

Tiniest Premature Children Face Problems as They Age Scientists are discovering that the lives of the smallest babies born prematurely grow more complicated over time. As the first large group of tiny babies -- those weighing less than 1,500 grams, or 3 pounds 4 ounces -- grows up, new research is showing that academic and behavioral problems often surface in the school years.

Nebraska Tries One Last Time In the more than seven years of his presidency, Bill Clinton has been to every state except Nebraska. Organizers of the Great Platte River Road Archway Monument hope to change that statistic before the president leaves office, and have invited him to the monument's dedication ceremony in July. But they are not holding their breath.
The president returned to Little Rock, Ark., to revisit memories of his political life in Arkansas and to preside over a fund-raising reception for his wife's bid for a Senate seat.

A Philosophy of Philanthrophy J. T. Houk of the National Heritage Foundation, one of the nation's largest charities, faces a challenge to what he claims is the cornerstone of his brand of philanthropy: finding ways to have donors and volunteers pay themselves for their charitable deeds. Many in the charitable world bridle at the notion that people should pay themselves to carry out their charitable impulses.

Utah Republican Faces Runoff A series of unpleasant incidents has made Representative Merrill Cook of Utah one of the country's most vulnerable House Republicans, in the view of Democrats. At the Republican State Convention in Salt Lake City, Mr. Cook failed to win enough votes to avoid a primary, and now faces a runoff vote.

Patients' Rights Bill Stalls White House officials and Democrats in Congress say they have become concerned that negotiations on a bill to define patients' rights have stalled. President Clinton has summoned 10 members of Congress to the White House in an effort to galvanize talks on the issue.
Crime Drops 7% Nationwide Serious crimes reported to the police dropped in 1999 for an eighth consecutive year, down 7 percent from the year before, the F.B.I. reported.

In Ritual for Cardinal, Faith in Everlasting Life Cardinal John O'Connor is to be honored today in a majestic and intricately planned funeral Mass that, though rooted in ancient traditions that viewed death as a bleak event, will celebrate what believers see as his ascension into heaven.

Senate Debates to Begin As the debate season begins this week in New Jersey in the race for United States Senate, the two Democrats, Jon S. Corzine and Jim Florio, will finally engage in direct give-and-take, and the Republicans, all but invisible in the news media, may actually get some attention.

Fumes Suspected in 6 Deaths Carbon monoxide fumes from a defective air-conditioning system are suspected to have killed six people at a house in Nassau County and left another victim hospitalized in critical condition, the police said.

Pataki Seeks DNA Reviews Gov. George E. Pataki proposed the creation of a state DNA review committee that would examine all convictions in New York overturned because of new genetic evidence. The panel would also propose regulations to improve the use of DNA profiling.

Egg-Frying Time Comes Early A heat wave smothered the New York metropolitan area and the mid-Atlantic states, shattering records. The temperature hit 93 degrees just after 3 p.m. in Central Park, breaking a record of 92 set in 1939.
Miami Beats Knicks The Knicks lost to the Miami Heat, 87-83, in the opening game of the second-round N.B.A. playoff series.
Douglas Fairbanks Jr. The debonair producer, bon vivant and Anglo-American ambassador without portfolio, who struggled to carve a distinctive acting career in the shadow of his father, was 90.
A Faster Way to Fly To attract business travelers, major airlines are spending tens of millions of dollars on new technology designed to whisk passengers through terminals more quickly.
Microsoft's Remedy Ideas Microsoft's suggested remedies in the antitrust case against it are due on Wednesday, and they are expected to consist mainly of proposals the company has already made.

Merger in Advertising Industry WPP Group, the British advertising conglomerate, is near to an agreement to buy Young & Rubicam for about $5.5 billion, executives close to the talks say, creating the largest ad agency merger in history.

New Tax System for Israel Israel's cabinet voted to overhaul the tax system for the first time in a quarter-century, backing a proposal for lower income tax rates balanced by new levies on inheritances, foreign earnings and capital gains.

Mea Culpa From Time Warner Time Warner's decision to block ABC in 3.5 million homes last week was an error, executives acknowledge, that came about through a legal miscalculation and a conviction that Disney, the owner of ABC, would back down in negotiations.
